details.misuse: لا يستخدم لتحديد حالات الحدوث في جانب واحد أو في الجانبين - حيث إن ذلك متعلق بتقييم قد يتضمن العديد من الأماكن
*Not for specifiying unilateral/bilateral occurence - this is related to an evaluation which perhaps includes multiple locations.(en)

details.purpose: To record details about a single physical site on, or within, the human body in terms of its relationship to other macroscopic anatomical landmarks.
details.use:
Use to record structured and consistent details about a single identified physical site on, or within, the human body by describing its location in relation to identified macroscopic anatomical landmarks. It may be necessary to describe the single physical location using more than one relative location - for example, 2 cm inferior to 'landmark A' AND 3 cm medial to 'landmark B'.
In practice, some archetypes carry a single data element for carrying a simple description of body site - for example, OBSERVATION.blood_pressure and CLUSTER.symptom when describing ear pain. In this situation, where the value set is predictable and simple to define, this single data element is a very accurate and pragmatic way to record the site in the body and to query at a later date. However in the situation where the anatomical location is not well defined or needs to be determined at run-time, it may be more flexible to use this structured archetype.
This archetype is specifically designed to be used within the context of any appropriate ENTRY or CLUSTER archetypes which supply the context of the identified body site, including insertion within the CLUSTER.anatomical_location if 'Body site name' or other data elements are also required.
Clinical use cases: - 5 cm inferior to the left tibial tuberosity - 2 cm medial to the right nipple - medial aspect of R great toe nail.
In the situation where the CLUSTER.anatomical_location can only be used to name a large and/or non-specific body part, the use of this archetype within the 'Complex Location' SLOT will support recording of a more precise location - for example, 2 cm anterior to the cubital fossa of the left forearm or 4 cm below R costal margin on the chest wall in the mid-clavicular line.
details.misuse:
Not to be used for specifying unilateral/bilateral occurrences of an anatomical feature.
Not to be used to specify a simple location of a named physical site in the body, such as left femur or medial aspect of nose. Use the CLUSTER.anatomical_location archetype for this purpose.

details.purpose: For registrering av detaljer om et anatomisk sted.
details.misuse: Anvendes ikke for spesifisering av unilateral/bilateral forekomst - dette relateres til en vurdering som kanskje omfatter flere steder.

translations.author: Haukeland University Hospital of Bergen, Norway
Lars Bitsch-Larsen
translations.accreditation: MD, DEAA, MBA, spec in anesthesia, spec in tropical medicine.

items.items: *A physical location on or within the human body that is described in terms of its relationship to other body parts.(en)
*Detail about the relative direction of the body site to the landmark.(en)

*Common aspects have been included as a value set, which can be extended over time, plus a free text option. Assumes that the body is being described while in the anatomical position. Occurrences are set to allow for a maximum of six directions to be recorded. Within this value set, clinicians will recognise that there are six mutually exclusive directional pairs - for example, a body site cannot be simultaneously 'medial to' and 'lateral to' an identical landmark. Other mutually exclusive pairs are 'Superior to' and 'Inferior to'; 'Anterior to' and 'Posterior to'; 'Proximal to' and 'Distal to'; 'Superficial to' and 'Deep to'; and 'Within' and 'External to'. Combinations made from one selection from within each of the six pair sets is potentially valid, although in clinical practice it will be very unlikely to need to simultaneously record more than two directions to describe a specified body site.(en)
المكان النسبي هو جانبي بالنسبة للمَعْلَم
المكان النسبي هو علويّ بالنسبة للمَعْلَم
المكان النسبي هو سفلي بالنسبة للمَعْلَم
*Detail to identify a single physical site either on, or within, the human body in terms of its relationship to other macroscopic anatomical landmarks.(en)
*More than one relative location may be required to provide an accurate cross reference.(en)
*Identified body site used as a reference point for the actual body site.(en)

*'Landmark name' can identify an anatomical structure (such as the umbilicus), an anatomical line (such as the mid-clavicular line), a well defined anatomical point (such as McBurney's point) or the 12 o'clock reference for the clock face position (such as the perineum in relationship to the anal canal with the patient in a lithotomy position) . This data element should be coded with a terminology capable of triggering decision support, where possible - an appropriate termset for use here could comprise individual concepts or a list of precoordinated terms. Free text should be used only if there is no appropriate terminology available. It is strongly recommended that 'Landmark name' be recorded as specifically as is anatomically possible. For example: record 'upper eyelid' rather than recording 'eyelid' with 'upper' as a qualifier; 'fifth rib' rather than 'rib' with a numeric qualifier. (en)
المسافة بين المكان و المَعْلَم المعروف
*Narrative description that be used to further refine and support the relative location structured data.(en)
*For example: a tattoo covers the bottom half of this area.(en)
*Detail about the relative direction of the body site to the landmark using an hour hand analogy from a clock face.(en)
*For example: the position of haemorrhoids in the anal canal are commonly described at 3 o'clock, 7 o'clock and 11 o'clock, with the perineum at 12 o'clock and patient in the lithotomy position.(en)
*A physical location on or within the human body that is described in terms of its relationship to other body parts.(en)
*Detail about the relative direction of the body site to the landmark.(en)

*Common aspects have been included as a value set, which can be extended over time, plus a free text option. Assumes that the body is being described while in the anatomical position. Occurrences are set to allow for a maximum of six directions to be recorded. Within this value set, clinicians will recognise that there are six mutually exclusive directional pairs - for example, a body site cannot be simultaneously 'medial to' and 'lateral to' an identical landmark. Other mutually exclusive pairs are 'Superior to' and 'Inferior to'; 'Anterior to' and 'Posterior to'; 'Proximal to' and 'Distal to'; 'Superficial to' and 'Deep to'; and 'Within' and 'External to'. Combinations made from one selection from within each of the six pair sets is potentially valid, although in clinical practice it will be very unlikely to need to simultaneously record more than two directions to describe a specified body site.(en)
*Detail to identify a single physical site either on, or within, the human body in terms of its relationship to other macroscopic anatomical landmarks.(en)
*More than one relative location may be required to provide an accurate cross reference.(en)
*Identified body site used as a reference point for the actual body site.(en)

*'Landmark name' can identify an anatomical structure (such as the umbilicus), an anatomical line (such as the mid-clavicular line), a well defined anatomical point (such as McBurney's point) or the 12 o'clock reference for the clock face position (such as the perineum in relationship to the anal canal with the patient in a lithotomy position) . This data element should be coded with a terminology capable of triggering decision support, where possible - an appropriate termset for use here could comprise individual concepts or a list of precoordinated terms. Free text should be used only if there is no appropriate terminology available. It is strongly recommended that 'Landmark name' be recorded as specifically as is anatomically possible. For example: record 'upper eyelid' rather than recording 'eyelid' with 'upper' as a qualifier; 'fifth rib' rather than 'rib' with a numeric qualifier. (en)
*Distance of location from the identified landmark.(en)
*Narrative description that be used to further refine and support the relative location structured data.(en)
*For example: a tattoo covers the bottom half of this area.(en)
*Detail about the relative direction of the body site to the landmark using an hour hand analogy from a clock face.(en)
*For example: the position of haemorrhoids in the anal canal are commonly described at 3 o'clock, 7 o'clock and 11 o'clock, with the perineum at 12 o'clock and patient in the lithotomy position.(en)
A physical location on or within the human body that is described in terms of its relationship to other body parts.
Detail about the relative direction of the body site to the landmark.

Common aspects have been included as a value set, which can be extended over time, plus a free text option. Assumes that the body is being described while in the anatomical position. Occurrences are set to allow for a maximum of six directions to be recorded. Within this value set, clinicians will recognise that there are six mutually exclusive directional pairs - for example, a body site cannot be simultaneously 'medial to' and 'lateral to' an identical landmark. Other mutually exclusive pairs are 'Superior to' and 'Inferior to'; 'Anterior to' and 'Posterior to'; 'Proximal to' and 'Distal to'; 'Superficial to' and 'Deep to'; and 'Within' and 'External to'. Combinations made from one selection from within each of the six pair sets is potentially valid, although in clinical practice it will be very unlikely to need to simultaneously record more than two directions to describe a specified body site.
Towards the middle, from the landmark.
Towards the side, from the landmark.
Above the landmark, often referring towards the head.
Below the landmark, often referring towards the feet.
Towards the front, or ventral aspect, from the landmark.
Towards the back, or dorsal aspect, from the landmark.
Detail to identify a single physical site either on, or within, the human body in terms of its relationship to other macroscopic anatomical landmarks.
More than one relative location may be required to provide an accurate cross reference.
Identified body site used as a reference point for the actual body site.

'Landmark name' can identify an anatomical structure (such as the umbilicus), an anatomical line (such as the mid-clavicular line), a well defined anatomical point (such as McBurney's point) or the 12 o'clock reference for the clock face position (such as the perineum in relationship to the anal canal with the patient in a lithotomy position) . This data element should be coded with a terminology capable of triggering decision support, where possible - an appropriate termset for use here could comprise individual concepts or a list of precoordinated terms. Free text should be used only if there is no appropriate terminology available. It is strongly recommended that 'Landmark name' be recorded as specifically as is anatomically possible. For example: record 'upper eyelid' rather than recording 'eyelid' with 'upper' as a qualifier; 'fifth rib' rather than 'rib' with a numeric qualifier.
Distance of location from the identified landmark.
Narrative description that be used to further refine and support the relative location structured data.
For example: a tattoo covers the bottom half of this area.
Image or other media used to support identification of the location on the body.
Closer to the body, relative to the landmark.
Further from the body, relative to the landmark.
Nearer the outer surface, relative to the landmark.
Further away from the outer surface, relative to the landmark.
Detail about the relative direction of the body site to the landmark using an hour hand analogy from a clock face.
For example: the position of haemorrhoids in the anal canal are commonly described at 3 o'clock, 7 o'clock and 11 o'clock, with the perineum at 12 o'clock and patient in the lithotomy position.
*A physical location on or within the human body that is described in terms of its relationship to other body parts.(en)
*Detail about the relative direction of the body site to the landmark.(en)

*Common aspects have been included as a value set, which can be extended over time, plus a free text option. Assumes that the body is being described while in the anatomical position. Occurrences are set to allow for a maximum of six directions to be recorded. Within this value set, clinicians will recognise that there are six mutually exclusive directional pairs - for example, a body site cannot be simultaneously 'medial to' and 'lateral to' an identical landmark. Other mutually exclusive pairs are 'Superior to' and 'Inferior to'; 'Anterior to' and 'Posterior to'; 'Proximal to' and 'Distal to'; 'Superficial to' and 'Deep to'; and 'Within' and 'External to'. Combinations made from one selection from within each of the six pair sets is potentially valid, although in clinical practice it will be very unlikely to need to simultaneously record more than two directions to describe a specified body site.(en)
Det relative sted medialt til landemerket.
Det relative sted lateralt for landemerket.
Det relative sted superiort til landemerket.
Det relative sted inferiort til landemerket.
Det relative sted anteriort til landemerket.
Det relative sted posteriort til landemerket.
*Detail to identify a single physical site either on, or within, the human body in terms of its relationship to other macroscopic anatomical landmarks.(en)
*More than one relative location may be required to provide an accurate cross reference.(en)
*Identified body site used as a reference point for the actual body site.(en)

*'Landmark name' can identify an anatomical structure (such as the umbilicus), an anatomical line (such as the mid-clavicular line), a well defined anatomical point (such as McBurney's point) or the 12 o'clock reference for the clock face position (such as the perineum in relationship to the anal canal with the patient in a lithotomy position) . Free text should be used only if there is no appropriate terminology available. It is strongly recommended that 'Landmark name' be recorded as specifically as is anatomically possible. For example: record 'upper eyelid' rather than recording 'eyelid' with 'upper' as a qualifier; 'fifth rib' rather than 'rib' with a numeric qualifier. (en)

*For example: a tattoo covers the bottom half of this area.(en)
